keyTakeAways: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American citizen, has been detained in Israeli prisons since February 2023 and is subjected to cold, inadequate living conditions and insufficient food.

He has lost considerable weight due to the poor conditions, including cold cells, meagre meals (e.g., three pieces of bread, a spoonful of labneh, undercooked rice, one sausage), and no fruit or dinner.
The case has become symbolic of the systemic mistreatment of minors in Israeli military detention, where children are prosecuted in military courts, a practice unique globally.

International human rights organizations, including Defense for Children International – Palestine (DCIP), have condemned the conditions, citing Israel as the only country that routinely prosecutes children in military courts.
Mohammed was detained after Israeli soldiers raided his family home in the occupied West Bank and reportedly beat him during transport.
He was initially held at Megiddo prison, described as a 'slaughterhouse', and later transferred to Ofer detention facility, both lacking heating or cooling systems.
His family, US lawmakers, and rights groups are urging the Trump administration to pressure Israel to release him, arguing that even a US passport cannot protect Palestinian children.
At least 79 Palestinian detainees have died in Israeli jails since October 2023 due to lack of medical care, poor food, and reports of torture.
Medical officials in Gaza have reported signs of torture and execution on bodies of Palestinian captives released in the recent ceasefire exchange.
Since 2022, Israeli forces have killed at least 10 US citizens, including two in the West Bank, raising concerns about US citizen safety in the occupied territories.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American teenager, has been detained in Israeli prisons since February 2023 following a raid on his family home in the occupied West Bank. He has endured severe conditions, including cold cells, meagre meals, lack of heating, and no fruit or dinner, leading to significant weight loss. His case has become a symbol of the systemic mistreatment of minors in Israeli military detention, where children are prosecuted under military courts—a practice unique globally. Human rights organizations, including Defense for Children International – Palestine (DCIP), have condemned the conditions, and U.S. lawmakers, including Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley, are urging the Trump administration to use diplomatic pressure to secure his release. The case is further highlighted by the deaths of at least 79 Palestinian detainees in Israeli jails since October 2023 and by reports of torture. Mohammed’s family and international advocates argue that even as a U.S. citizen, he is not protected, and the broader context includes rising concerns over US citizen safety in the region due to Israeli military actions.
title: Cold cells, meagre meals: Palestinian American boy suffers in Israeli jail
